name: Carlton D'Silva
cooked:
@21f3000745 @24f1001824

You can get your free key from here:

aipipe.org

AI Pipe | Login

It is documented here:

github.com

GitHub - sanand0/aipipe: Gives anyone access to an OpenAI/OpenRouter API...

Gives anyone access to an OpenAI/OpenRouter API key free at 10 cents/week. Self-hostable. Useful as a backend if you're building pure front-end LLM apps

You can use the AI Pipe Token from aipipe.org/login in any OpenAI API compatible application by setting:

OPENAI_API_KEY as your AI Pipe Token

OPENAI_BASE_URL as https://aipipe.org/openai/v1

eg. (in Linux BASH)

export OPENAI_API_KEY=your_aipipe_token_goes_here

export OPENAI_BASE_URL="https://aipipe.org/openai/v1"

Then if you have uv installed

Note: The tool previously named uvx is now uvenv due to a naming collision with a new uv command. The new name better reflects its purpose, combining uv with venv .
It’s been used here so that those who are familiar with uvx can understand the below command. It is always good practise to migrate away from deprecated tools to newer maintained ones because deprecated tools are easy targets of open-source supply chain code injection attacks.
uvx is not the same as the python library uvx. uvx here is a command within uv.

uvx openai api chat.completions.create -m gpt-4.1-nano -g user "Hello. Give me 5 names for a pet dog."

or

uvx llm 'Hello. What is 2 + 2?' -m gpt-4.1-nano --key $OPENAI_API_KEY

link_counts.title: GitHub - sanand0/aipipe: Gives anyone access to an OpenAI/OpenRouter API key free at 10 cents/week. Self-hostable. Useful as a backend if you're building pure front-end LLM apps

name: Carlton D'Silva
cooked:
The seek portal is not linked with the TDS exam server. Therefore only what the exam portal says will be the accurate score. Each submission you Save is recorded. The result of your last three submissions can be reloaded in the exam portal for TDS. The last saved submission is your official score.

tds_ga_recent_save943×762 60.1 KB

The seek portal is typically used only for announcements and feedback. The entirety of TDS is handled by our own portal. (The exception being the end term). If there is something that we require you to do in the seek portal we will communicate that to you via email or discourse or through the TDS portal.

Kind regards

name: Advaith Sanil Kumar
cooked:
There’s a folder that corresponds to your WSL on your system, would look something like \\wsl.localhost\<distribution-name>. All the folders and files you create in WSL will be here.

You can always just copy your files manually into this location, or for a more robust solution you can use a symlink:
https://superuser.com/questions/1534330/access-downloaded-files-from-wsl

name: Anand S
cooked:
@GyanPrakashKushwaha

Because you’re still hitting “Cannot allocate memory” (ENOMEM) during the wheel-unpack step, rebooting won’t help if your Linux environment simply has too little RAM and no swap. In WSL (and many small VMs or containers) you often end up with zero swap space and a hard cap on RAM—so even a modest Python-install can blow past your available memory.

What’s happening under the hood:

  • uv run spins up a fresh venv and calls pip install certifi.
  • Pip unpacks the .whl entirely in RAM (or into a tmpfs), which on a low-RAM, swapless system exhausts all allocatable pages.
  • The kernel refuses the allocation and throws “os error 12.”

How to fix

  1. Add or enlarge swap

    sudo fallocate -l 2G /swapfile
sudo chmod 600 /swapfile
sudo mkswap /swapfile
sudo swapon /swapfile

    Then confirm with free -h that you now have swap available.

  2. Raise WSL memory limits (if you’re on WSL2)
    In your Windows user folder, create or edit ~/.wslconfig:

    [wsl2]
memory=4GB   # or higher
swap=2GB     # enable swap file for WSL

    Then wsl --shutdown and restart your distro.

  3. Use a persistent venv
    Instead of recreating a fresh env every time with uv run, make one once:

    python3 -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate
pip install httpie

    Then invoke your script inside that env so you’re not reinstalling wheels on every run.

  4. Install without isolation or cache (less RAM-hungry)

    PIP_NO_CACHE_DIR=off pip install --no-build-isolation certifi

    This skips some in-memory build steps.

Any of these will prevent the ENOMEM you’re seeing. Once you’ve got swap or more RAM, the certifi wheel will install cleanly.

name: Sameer Thakur
cooked:
you have to type a javascript code in console

function countWeekendDays(start, end) {
let startDate = new Date(start);
let endDate = new Date(end);
let count = 0;
while (startDate <= endDate) {
let day = startDate.getDay();
if (day === 0 || day === 6) { // 0 = Sunday, 6 = Saturday
count++;
}
startDate.setDate(startDate.getDate() + 1);
}
return count;
}

// Example usage:
console.log(countWeekendDays(‘1981-06-12’, ‘2008-11-08’));

name: Anirudh
cooked:
du was originally meant to give disk usage, not file size. The -b flag was added to provide file size, but this does not work on macOS, so YMMV with that.

What worked for me was using the -ls flag on the find command and feeding the 7th value to the awk function:

find . -type f -size +{$QSIZE-1}c -newermt "{$QDATE}" -ls | awk '{ total += $7 } END { print total }

(define QSIZE and QDATE as your question specifies)

cooked:
Hey Guys for the Question 14 i have used this python script to compute the value

import pandas as pd
df1 = pd.read_csv('data1.csv', encoding='cp1252')
df2 = pd.read_csv('data2.csv', encoding='utf-8')
df3 = pd.read_csv('data3.txt', encoding='utf-16-le', sep='\t')
df = pd.concat([df1, df2, df3], ignore_index=True)
symbols = ['˜', 'ƒ', '‹']
filtered = df[df['symbol'].isin(symbols)]
total = filtered['value'].sum()
print(total)

and i have recieved the ouput as
12279
its showing as incorrect answer , could any of you guys help me out ?

name: SIDDHARTH M
cooked:
Guys I have Figured it myself

cd symbols-data/

# Convert CP-1252 to UTF-8
iconv -f CP1252 -t UTF-8 data1.csv -o data1_utf8.csv

# data2.csv is already UTF-8, just copy
cp data2.csv data2_utf8.csv

# Convert UTF-16 to UTF-8 and handle tabs
iconv -f UTF-16 -t UTF-8 data3.txt | tr '\t' ',' > data3_utf8.csv


cat data*_utf8.csv | awk -F',' '$1 ~ /^[˜ƒ‹]$/ { sum += $2 } END { print sum }'

followed these instructions and i got the answer

name: Siva.Meikanda Sivam
cooked:
you can use the /mnt/c/ (or /mnt/d/, /mnt/e/, etc., depending on your drive on windows) path inside WSL to directly access files from your Windows file system without having to manually copy them over.

So instead of copying downloaded files from Windows into WSL, you can directly navigate to the Downloads folder in WSL like this:

cd /mnt/c/Users/<YourWindowsUsername>/Downloads

( or )
you can also switch to different drive (or partion) and work on the files there

and the :Zone.Identifier file is just a hidden metadata about your downloaded file in windows giving info about where it came from . the windows file system adds this data for Security related purpose wheather to warn you about it or not , since the filesystems are different between windows and wsl . linux is considering that metadata as separate file . that why you get :Zone.identifier file for each file or folder .

if you know that a file is trustworthy you can delete :Zone.identifier file

image829×608 31 KB

name: Bharath
cooked:
aipipe.org is acting as a third-party proxy for OpenAI’s API, exposing a compatible endpoint at:

https://aipipe.org/openai/v1

They allow users to interact with OpenAI-compatible models using a similar API structure (e.g., chat/completions, completions, etc.), but routed through their service, not directly to OpenAI.

name: Arun Kumar Tiwari
cooked:
a. First go to ubantu/home, delete .venv, llm-env folder if exists in file explorer.
b. Restart ubantu terminal

Commands step by step

  1. sudo apt install python3-venv python-full
  2. python3 -m venv ~/llm-env
  3. source ~/llm-env/bin/activate
  4. pip install --upgrade pip
  5. pip install llm openai
  6. llm keys set openai
  7. Enter Key: ( you have to go on AI Pipe | Login and copy and paste Ai pipe Token here)
  8. export OPENAI _API_KEY=(your Token from platform.openai.com/api-keys)
  9. export OPENAI_BASE_URL=https://aipipe.org/openai/V1

Follow above steps strictly and then test
llm “what is 2 + 2?”

It will be definitely helpful.

name: Arun Kumar Tiwari
cooked:
a. First go to ubantu/home, delete .venv, llm-env folder if exists in file explorer.
b. Restart ubantu terminal

Commands step by step

  1. sudo apt install python3-venv python-full
  2. python3 -m venv ~/llm-env
  3. source ~/llm-env/bin/activate
  4. pip install --upgrade pip
  5. pip install llm openai
  6. llm keys set openai
  7. Enter Key: ( you have to go on AI Pipe | Login and copy and paste Ai pipe Token here)
  8. export OPENAI _API_KEY=(your Token from platform.openai.com/api-keys)
  9. export OPENAI_BASE_URL=https://aipipe.org/openai/V1

Follow above steps strictly and then test
llm “what is 2 + 2?”

It will be definitely helpful.

name: Carlton D'Silva

name: Carlton D'Silva
cooked: There is no answer key for GAs. Most questions are parameterised for each student. If you want to know how to solve a certain GA question you can ask in the live session or in discourse. Since there are many correct ways to get to the answer there is not one prescribed way.

name: SIDDHARTH M
cooked: Thanks it worked out. Is it the problem with the variables that gets expired or what could be the issue.

name: Jivraj Singh Shekhawat
cooked:
Hi @SIDDHARTH_M

Yes variables are bound to your terminal session, as soon as you close terminal they are not available. If you want to make them permanent then keep them in configuration file (if you are using bash shell then add export commands to .bashrc )

Generated by tds-virtual-ta ChatGPT - Configuring Variables in Bash

Kind regards
